top_categories.workout_context: Pisgah Monster Cross' Pisgah National Forest gravel (60%), Singletrack/dirt (40%) forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 50 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Pisgah Monster Cross' demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before October.
At Pisgah Monster Cross, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
160ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Pisgah Monster Cross, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
8,000ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
8,000ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Pisgah Monster Cross. Train it until it feels boring.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on pisgah National Forest—technical Appalachian. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Smooth pedaling at 50 miles saves muscle. Bad technique at mile 10 is invisible. At mile 80 it's a cramp.
50 miles on pisgah National Forest—technical Appalachian burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
Low-cadence force work for 8,000ft of climbing. The slow, grinding ascents where you can't spin—you push.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Pisgah Monster Cross’s 50 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.altitude: Moderate altitude at Pisgah Monster Cross. Arrive 2–3 days early. Reduce intensity expectations by 5–10%. Hydrate aggressively.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Pisgah Monster Cross demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride pisgah national forest—technical appalachian terrain at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: pisgah national forest gravel (60%), singletrack/dirt (40%), technical appalachian terrain. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 50 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and Over Under to prepare you for 50 miles of pisgah national forest—technical appalachian terrain in Brevard, North Carolina (Pisgah National Forest).
